content.body: selection in shadow DOM issue will have its birthday in a month: https://www.w3.org/Bugs/Public/show_bug.cgi?id=15444 , later https://github.com/WICG/webcomponents/issues/79
Maybe make a cake in the shape of a "10", and give it a selection of fillings.
Noam Rosenthal: if they are indistinguishable in your editor, I recommend copying from https://infra.spec.whatwg.org/#lists
content.formatted_body: Noam Rosenthal: if they are indistinguishable in your editor, I recommend copying from https://infra.spec.whatwg.org/#lists

content.body: gotcha annevk. I must say I find these ambiguous unicode characters in specs somewhat cumbersome...
content.formatted_body: gotcha annevk. I must say I find these ambiguous unicode characters in specs somewhat cumbersome...

content.body: annevk: regarding `allow preloads` and custom headers, how would you suggest to ignore preloads when custom XHR/fetch() headers are present?
content.formatted_body: annevk: regarding allow preloads and custom headers, how would you suggest to ignore preloads when custom XHR/fetch() headers are present?

content.body: Noam Rosenthal: I think the presence of any header would indicate a custom header
content.formatted_body: Noam Rosenthal: I think the presence of any header would indicate a custom header

content.body: Noam Rosenthal: you can guard the check with "unsafe-request flag" which only fetch() and XHR set
content.formatted_body: Noam Rosenthal: you can guard the check with "unsafe-request flag" which only fetch() and XHR set

content.body: As for the Unicode characters, they generally seem to work okay for me as long as I copy-and-paste. Could you elaborate on what makes them cumbersome?
they're cumbersome because mistakes are not visible to the naked eye
and they're not common characters in other forms of programming, and don't appear on keyboards
I think that makes them unique among characters used in specs, but I might be wrong about that
Well, the precedent here is JavaScript, which uses the same characters for its internal List type
Yea, I figured there's some historical reason for this
@annevk: regarding "allow preloads", I thought to keep it for now for the "sync XHR" case, I don't think there's another way for fetch to know that this is a case where preload should be avoided
Noam Rosenthal: sync xhr always bypasses preloads? I didn't know. Seems somewhat unfortunate to give sync xhr a special ability. Might make people want to use it more.
content.formatted_body: Noam Rosenthal: sync xhr always bypasses preloads? I didn't know. Seems somewhat unfortunate to give sync xhr a special ability. Might make people want to use it more.

content.body: annevk: yea, actually I should dig more into why chrome does that. I don't think other implementations do. Maybe that part should be outside the spec for now and added separately with a separate discussion
content.formatted_body: annevk: yea, actually I should dig more into why chrome does that. I don't think other implementations do. Maybe that part should be outside the spec for now and added separately with a separate discussion
